feed.title: Over Half of Replace-by-Fee-Rate Replacements Are Mined

entry.title: Over Half of Replace-by-Fee-Rate Replacements Are Mined
entry.summary:
Understanding the dynamics of transaction fees on the Bitcoin network can provide insightful strategies for both preventing Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks and optimizing Replace-By-Fee (RBF) mechanisms. The process involves closely monitoring two critical metrics from the mempool: the purging fee rate (P) and the next block fee rate (N). An attacker seeking to maximize transaction replacements within the mempool would start by setting a transaction's fee rate slightly above P and incrementally increase it, multiplying by a coefficient K, until it matches N. The effectiveness of such an attack is contingent upon the relationship between N, P, and K, with the potential number of replacements being quantifiable through the formula floor(log(K, N/P)).
Given the current values where N equals 11 satoshis per byte and P is at 1.13 satoshis per byte, the impact of varying K is notable. For instance, setting K to 2 results in three possible replacements, while K at 1.25 increases this number to ten, and further adjusting K to 1.1 skyrockets the possible replacements to twenty-three. This mathematical exploration underscores the significance of archival data on P and N rates for assessing the historical vulnerability of the Bitcoin network to such exploitation tactics. Maximizing the ratio of N to P gives a clearer picture of the worst-case scenarios in past attacks.
The strategic pricing of DoS attacks versus legitimate uses of RBF further delves into the economics behind transaction fees. The cost-effectiveness of launching a DoS attack inversely correlates with the logarithm of K, whereas the expense for a legitimate user employing RBF is directly proportional to the difference between K and a fraction of N over R, where R represents the original fee rate of the transaction. A potential mitigation strategy involves setting K to the median value of N over R across transactions, effectively nullifying the cost for average users while imposing a financial deterrent on attackers.
A practical implementation for determining sufficient fee rate increases during RBF can leverage simple arithmetic operations on the CFeeRate object, illustrating that even modest adjustments in fee rates can be efficiently evaluated to ensure they meet predefined thresholds. This approach not only simplifies the programming logic but also aligns with the overarching goal of balancing accessibility for genuine transactions against the costs imposed on malicious activities.
